fun_fact: A single fish sold for $3.1 million at Tokyo's Tsukiji Market in 2019.
explanation: Bluefin tuna is a nutrient-dense powerhouse, rich in protein, omega-3s, and vitamin D. You've been eating this fish for centuries, just like your ancestors – it's a traditional food that's been a staple in many cultures. This is the real deal, not some farmed imitation.

name: bluefish
fun_fact: Bluefish are such aggressive predators they sometimes keep killing even after they're full.
explanation: Bluefish is a nutrient-dense fish that's been a staple for coastal communities for centuries. Rich in omega-3s and vitamins, it's a great source of protein for your body. You're getting a real meal when you eat bluefish, not some factory-farmed imitation.

name: bonito
fun_fact: Dried and shaved into katsuobushi, the foundation of Japanese dashi stock.
explanation: Bonito is a nutrient-dense fish rich in vitamin D and selenium, essential for immune function and thyroid health. Its traditional use in Japanese cuisine as a base for dashi broth showcases its value as a whole food. You'll find it's a better choice than many other fish due to its low mercury levels.

name: branzino
fun_fact: Branzino is one of the most popular fish in Mediterranean cuisine.
explanation: Branzino is a nutrient-dense fish rich in selenium and vitamin D, crucial for immune function and bone health. You evolved to eat this delicate Mediterranean fish, and its mild flavor and flaky texture make it a genuine pleasure. One of the finest fish you can put on your plate.

name: bream
fun_fact: The gilt-head bream was sacred to Aphrodite in ancient Greece.
explanation: Bream is a nutrient-dense fish that's been a staple in traditional diets for centuries. Rich in omega-3s and protein, it's a perfect example of a whole food your body was designed to eat. One of the best fish you can put on your plate.

name: butterfish
fun_fact: So rich and oily that Japan classifies it as 'shiro maguro' (white tuna).
explanation: Butterfish is a nutrient-dense fish rich in selenium and omega-3s your body craves. It's a traditional catch in many coastal cultures, where it's been consumed for centuries. Eat it whole, with the bones and skin, for maximum nutritional benefit.

name: carp
fun_fact: Koi fish are just selectively bred carp that can live over 200 years.
explanation: Carp is a nutrient-dense fish that's been a staple in traditional diets for centuries. Rich in protein, omega-3s, and minerals like selenium, it's a great source of energy for your body. You should be eating this fish, not the farmed, factory-farmed kind.

name: catfish
fun_fact: Catfish have over 100,000 taste buds — covering their entire body.
explanation: Catfish is a nutrient-dense fish that's been a staple in traditional diets for centuries. Rich in protein, omega-3s, and various vitamins and minerals, it's a great source of energy and sustenance. Your body is designed to thrive on this type of food, not the processed stuff.

name: ceviche
fun_fact: Not technically 'cooked' — citric acid denatures the proteins just like heat does.
explanation: Ceviche is raw fish marinated in citrus juice, just like your ancestors did in coastal cultures. The acidity helps break down the proteins, making the nutrients more accessible. It's a traditional way to eat fish, rich in omega-3s and other essential nutrients.

name: chilean sea bass
fun_fact: Actually called Patagonian toothfish — renamed for marketing because nobody wanted to order 'toothfish'.
explanation: Chilean sea bass is a nutrient-dense fish that's rich in selenium and omega-3s. You're getting a fish that's been hunted for centuries, making it a traditional, whole food. Eat it wild-caught and you're getting a meal that's as close to nature as it gets.

name: cobia
fun_fact: Cobia have no swim bladder and must keep swimming to avoid sinking.
explanation: Cobia is a nutrient-dense fish that provides a boost of protein and omega-3s your body craves. A staple in many traditional diets, its mild flavor and firm texture make it a great option for grilling or baking. One of the best and underappreciated fish you can eat.

name: cod
fun_fact: Cod was so important to early American history that a wooden carving of one hangs in the Massachusetts State House.
explanation: Cod is a nutrient-dense fish you're meant to eat, rich in protein and low in mercury. It's been a staple in coastal diets for centuries, with its firm texture and mild flavor making it a perfect catch. Your body doesn't need much more than this.

name: corvina
fun_fact: A prized ceviche fish in Peru and Central America.
explanation: Corvina is a nutrient-dense fish rich in selenium and omega-3s, with a robust flavor profile that's been prized by coastal cultures for centuries. You can't find this in a lab or a factory, only in the wild. One of the hidden gems of the sea.

name: dorado
fun_fact: Not a dolphin — the name 'dolphinfish' has caused confusion for decades.
explanation: Dorado is a dense source of protein and vitamins your body craves. As a wild-caught fish, it's a traditional food source that's been on menus for centuries. One of the healthiest fish you can eat, with a fatty acid profile that's off the charts.

name: dory
fun_fact: Has a distinctive dark spot on its side — legend says it's St. Peter's thumbprint.
explanation: Dory is a nutrient-dense fish option, rich in selenium and vitamin D that your body actually uses. You've been eating this for centuries – it's a traditional catch in many coastal cultures. Wild-caught dory is one of the best things you can eat.

name: drum
fun_fact: Makes a drumming sound using its swim bladder — that's how it got its name.
explanation: Drum is a nutrient-dense fish rich in selenium and protein. A traditional catch in the Gulf of Mexico, it's a fish your ancestors likely ate – and it's still a great choice today. One of the best fish you can eat, period.

name: eel
fun_fact: No one has ever observed eels mating — their reproduction is one of nature's biggest mysteries.
explanation: Eel is a nutrient-dense fish rich in protein, vitamins, and minerals. Your ancestors caught it from rivers and oceans, where it still thrives today. Eating eel is a blast from the past, one of the best ways to get the nutrients your body was meant to have.

name: escolar
fun_fact: Contains indigestible wax esters — Japan requires warning labels on it.
explanation: Escolar is a fatty fish rich in vitamins and minerals, and its meat is high in omega-3s, a nutrient your body was designed to utilize. As a traditional food source in many coastal cultures, escolar has been consumed for centuries. Its unique flavor and texture make it a prized catch.

name: flounder
fun_fact: Flounder are born with eyes on both sides but one eye migrates as they grow.
explanation: Flounder is a lean protein rich in selenium and vitamin D, nutrients your body relies on for immune function and bone health. You'll find it on menus in coastal towns worldwide, where it's been a staple for centuries. One of the healthiest fish you can eat.

name: flying fish
fun_fact: Can glide up to 200 meters using wing-like fins — the national symbol of Barbados.
explanation: Flying fish are a nutrient-dense catch, rich in omega-3s and protein to fuel your body. You've been eating them for centuries, a staple in many coastal cultures. One of the most impressive fish in the sea, and one of the best things you can eat.

name: garfish
fun_fact: Has bright green bones, which alarms people but is perfectly safe.
explanation: Garfish is a nutrient-dense fish rich in vitamin D and omega-3s your body craves. Its low mercury levels make it a safe choice for frequent consumption. A traditional catch for coastal communities, garfish is a whole food your ancestors likely ate.

name: golden trout
fun_fact: California's state freshwater fish, found only in high Sierra Nevada streams.
explanation: Golden trout is a nutrient-dense fish rich in protein and omega-3s your body craves. Native to clear mountain streams, it's a traditional catch for anglers and a staple in many mountain communities. One of the most pristine fish you can eat.

name: grilled fish
fun_fact: The simplest preparation for the best fish — heat, salt, and time.
explanation: You're getting a dose of the ocean's best: protein, omega-3s, and minerals. Grilled fish is a traditional way to cook this nutrient-dense food, preserving its delicate flavor and nutrients. It's one of the closest things to eating a wild fish straight from the sea.

name: grouper
fun_fact: Some grouper species can change sex from female to male as they age.
explanation: Grouper is a nutrient-dense fish that's been a staple in coastal cultures for centuries. Rich in protein, vitamins, and minerals, it's a real food that supports your body's needs. One of the best seafood options you can choose.

name: gurnard
fun_fact: Walks along the ocean floor on modified fins that look like legs.
explanation: Gurnard is a nutrient-dense fish rich in selenium, vitamin D, and omega-3s your body craves. You've been eating its relatives for thousands of years, from ancient Greeks to modern-day Mediterranean diets. One of the most overlooked yet valuable fish on the planet.

name: haddock
fun_fact: Haddock has a distinctive dark blotch on each side called 'Saint Peter's thumbprint.'
explanation: Haddock is a nutrient-dense fish that's been a staple in coastal diets for centuries. Rich in selenium, vitamin D, and omega-3s, it's an excellent choice for supporting the immune system and brain function. You're getting a real, unprocessed food that's been fueling humans for generations.

name: hake
fun_fact: The most popular fish in Spain, where it outsells cod and salmon combined.
explanation: Hake is a nutrient-dense fish rich in protein, selenium, and iodine. You've been eating it for centuries, just like your ancestors did in Spain and Portugal. One of the many reasons to love this underappreciated catch.

name: halibut
fun_fact: Halibut can weigh over 500 pounds and live for more than 50 years.
explanation: Halibut is a nutrient-dense fish rich in vitamin D and selenium, crucial for immune function and thyroid health. You've been eating it for centuries in traditional coastal diets, where it's a staple. One of the best sources of protein you can put on your plate.

name: herring
fun_fact: Herring communicate by releasing bubbles from their rear end — scientists call it 'fast repetitive tick' sounds.
explanation: Herring is a nutrient-dense fish that's been a staple in many traditional diets for centuries. Rich in omega-3s, vitamins, and minerals, it's a food your body was designed to eat. One of the smallest, yet most potent, fish you can put on your plate.

name: horse mackerel
fun_fact: Not a true mackerel — called 'aji' in Japanese sushi restaurants.
explanation: Horse mackerel is a nutrient-dense fish rich in omega-3s and vitamin D, which your body uses to regulate everything from mood to immune function. You were meant to eat this, not some farmed abomination. One of the best fish you can eat.

name: john dory
fun_fact: John Dory has a distinctive dark spot on each side, said to be Saint Peter's thumbprint.
explanation: John dory is a mild-flavored fish rich in selenium and B12, nutrients your body demands. Its delicate taste and flaky texture make it a traditional catch in coastal cuisine, where it's been prized for centuries. One of the unsung heroes of the sea.

name: kingfish
fun_fact: Prized in Indian and Middle Eastern cuisines for its firm, flavorful flesh.
explanation: Kingfish is a nutrient-dense catch, rich in protein and omega-3s your body craves. Wild-caught kingfish is a traditional food source in many coastal cultures, where it's been consumed for centuries. It's one of the best fish options for a healthy diet.

name: lamprey
fun_fact: A jawless fish considered a delicacy since Roman times — still served in Portugal.
explanation: Lamprey is a nutrient-dense, ancient food that's been consumed by humans for thousands of years. Its rich, oily flesh is packed with vitamins and minerals, and its unique gelatinous texture is a sign of its high collagen content. You're getting a taste of what our ancestors ate.

name: lemon sole
fun_fact: Neither made of lemons nor a true sole — it's actually a type of flounder.
explanation: Lemon sole is a rich source of selenium and vitamin D, two nutrients your body craves. This delicate flatfish has been a staple in traditional European cuisine for centuries. When you eat lemon sole, you're getting a taste of the ocean's bounty, just as nature intended.

name: ling
fun_fact: A deep-water relative of cod that can grow over 6 feet long.
explanation: Ling is a nutrient-dense fish rich in selenium and vitamin D, which your body needs to function properly. It's a traditional catch in many coastal cultures, often dried or smoked to preserve its rich flavor. One of the unsung heroes of the ocean, ling is a great choice for a healthy meal.

name: lingcod
fun_fact: Lingcod sometimes have bright blue or green flesh, which turns white when cooked.
explanation: Lingcod is a nutrient-dense fish that's been a staple for coastal communities for centuries. Its rich flavor and firm texture make it a great source of protein and omega-3s. You're getting a real meal when you eat wild-caught lingcod.

name: mackerel
fun_fact: Mackerel can swim at speeds of up to 33 miles per hour.
explanation: Mackerel is a nutrient-dense powerhouse that's bursting with omega-3s, vitamins, and minerals your body craves. You'll find it's been a staple in traditional diets for centuries, providing the energy and sustenance humans need to thrive. Eat it raw or smoked, and reap the rewards of this incredible fish.

name: mahi mahi
fun_fact: Mahi mahi means 'strong strong' in Hawaiian.
explanation: Mahi mahi is a nutrient-dense fish rich in protein, vitamin D, and selenium. You've been eating it for centuries, just like the ancient Hawaiians, who prized it for its flavor and nutritional value. A whole, wild-caught mahi mahi is one of the best things you can put on your plate.

name: mako shark
fun_fact: The fastest shark species at 60 mph — its meat tastes like swordfish.
explanation: Mako shark is a fatty fish rich in omega-3s and vitamins, but its high mercury levels are a concern. You're better off choosing smaller, lower-mercury fish options like sardines or herring. However, mako shark is still a nutrient-dense choice for those who can handle the risk.

name: milkfish
fun_fact: The national fish of the Philippines — deboning it is an art form.
explanation: Milkfish is a nutrient-dense fish that's been a staple in Southeast Asian cuisine for centuries. Rich in protein, omega-3s, and vitamins, it's an excellent source of energy and essential nutrients your body craves. A traditional, unprocessed food that's been fueling communities for generations.

name: monchong
fun_fact: A Hawaiian deep-water fish with rich, buttery flesh — underappreciated on the mainland.
explanation: Monchong is a traditional catch in Hawaiian waters, rich in protein and omega-3s your body craves. Its firm texture and mild flavor make it a staple in Pacific Island cuisine. One of the most underrated fish you can eat, monchong is a true ocean gem.

name: monkfish
fun_fact: Monkfish is called 'poor man's lobster' because its tail meat has a similar texture.
explanation: Monkfish is a nutrient-dense catch, offering a rich source of protein and essential minerals like selenium and iodine. In traditional Japanese cuisine, it's revered for its delicate flavor and firm texture. You're getting a genuine, unadulterated seafood experience with monkfish.

name: mullet
fun_fact: Its dried, cured roe (bottarga) is called 'the poor man's caviar'.
explanation: Mullet is rich in omega-3s and B vitamins, essential for brain function and energy production. You've been eating this fish for centuries, from ancient Romans to modern-day seafood lovers. One of the most underrated fish you can eat.

name: ocean perch
fun_fact: Not a true perch — it's a rockfish that can live over 100 years.
explanation: Ocean perch is a nutrient-dense catch, rich in selenium and B vitamins your body craves. You've been eating this fish for centuries, from traditional coastal communities to modern-day markets. A sustainable choice, ocean perch is one of the best fish you can put on your plate.

name: opah
fun_fact: Opah is the only known fully warm-blooded fish.
explanation: Opah is a nutrient-dense fish with a rich profile of vitamins A and D, along with a healthy dose of omega-3s. It's a traditional catch in Hawaiian and Mediterranean cuisine, where you'd find it grilled or broiled fresh off the boat. One of the most impressive fish in the sea, opah is a real treat.

name: opakapaka
fun_fact: A prized Hawaiian deep-water snapper with delicate pink flesh.
explanation: Opakapaka is a nutrient-dense fish rich in selenium and omega-3s your body uses to regulate inflammation. This Hawaiian snapper has been a staple in traditional Polynesian diets for centuries, making it a real food you can trust. You're getting a taste of the Pacific's bounty with each bite.

name: orange roughy
fun_fact: Can live up to 149 years — the fish on your plate may have been born before World War I.
explanation: You're not going to find a more traditional, ocean-dwelling fish than orange roughy, which has been a staple for coastal communities for centuries. Rich in protein and omega-3s, this deep-sea catch is a nutrient-dense choice that's been part of the human diet for thousands of years. Eat it and feel like you're eating like your ancestors.

name: pacific halibut
fun_fact: Can grow to 500 pounds — the largest flatfish in the Pacific Ocean.
explanation: Pacific halibut is a nutrient-dense fish that's been a staple for coastal communities for centuries. Rich in protein, omega-3s, and selenium, it's a food your body was designed to thrive on. One of the healthiest fish you can eat, hands down.

name: pacific saury
fun_fact: Grilled sanma is the taste of autumn in Japan — served with grated daikon.
explanation: Pacific saury is a nutrient-dense fish rich in vitamin D and selenium, essential for immune function and thyroid health. Its traditional use in Japanese cuisine speaks to its value as a sustainable, whole food. You're doing your body a favor by choosing this underappreciated catch.

name: parrotfish
fun_fact: Eats coral and poops sand — a single parrotfish creates 200 lbs of sand per year.
explanation: Parrotfish are a nutrient-dense catch, teeming with vitamin D your body craves. As a traditional seafood staple in many coastal cultures, you can trust that parrotfish has been a healthy part of the human diet for centuries. Rich in protein and minerals, this fish is a top choice for a well-rounded meal.

name: perch
fun_fact: Perch are one of the most widely distributed freshwater fish in North America.
explanation: Perch is a nutrient-dense fish rich in protein, omega-3s, and vitamin D. You've been eating it for centuries in traditional European and Asian cuisines. One of the best freshwater options, its flavor and texture are hard to beat.

name: pike
fun_fact: Northern pike can live over 25 years and have razor-sharp teeth.
explanation: Pike is a lean, high-protein fish that's rich in vitamin D and selenium, two nutrients your body craves. It's a traditional catch in the Northern Hemisphere, where humans have been eating it for centuries. You're getting a nutrient-dense meal when you choose wild-caught pike.

name: plaice
fun_fact: The bright orange spots make it one of the most recognizable flatfish.
explanation: Plaice is a nutrient-dense fish that's been a staple in coastal diets for centuries. Rich in omega-3s and essential minerals, it's an excellent choice for you. A traditional catch that's been fueling human bodies for generations.

name: pollock
fun_fact: Most imitation crab meat is actually made from pollock.
explanation: Pollock is a nutrient-dense fish rich in protein, omega-3s, and B vitamins. Traditionally caught by small-scale fishermen, it's a sustainable seafood option for you. A mild-flavored fish that's been a staple in coastal diets for centuries, pollock is a real food worth eating.

name: pompano
fun_fact: Pompano is considered one of the finest eating fish in the Gulf of Mexico.
explanation: Pompano is a nutrient-dense fish rich in selenium and vitamin D, a crucial nutrient for immune function. Traditionally caught in the wild, its mild flavor and firm texture make it a staple in many coastal cuisines. This ancient food source is exactly what your body needs.

name: red snapper
fun_fact: One of the most mislabeled fish — studies show 87% of 'red snapper' in restaurants isn't.
explanation: Red snapper is a nutrient-dense fish rich in selenium and protein. You've been eating this fish for centuries in the Gulf Coast, where it's a staple. One of the healthiest fish options you can put on your plate.

name: rockfish
fun_fact: There are over 100 species of rockfish along the Pacific coast.
explanation: Rockfish is a nutrient-dense fish option, providing you with selenium, vitamin D, and omega-3s. You've been eating this species for centuries in various forms, from dried to smoked. It's a true catch for your plate, offering a robust flavor and a healthy dose of fatty acids.

name: rohu
fun_fact: The king of Bengali fish curries — served at every celebration.
explanation: Rohu is a nutrient-dense fish rich in omega-3s and protein, exactly what your body was designed to run on. This ancient fish has been on menus for thousands of years in traditional Indian cuisine, a testament to its enduring value. One of the best whole fish options you can sink your teeth into.

name: salmon
fun_fact: Salmon can jump up to 12 feet in the air to get past waterfalls.
explanation: Salmon is packed with omega-3s your brain actually needs. Wild-caught is king — farmed is acceptable but not the same animal. One of the best things you can eat.

name: sardine
fun_fact: Sardines are named after the Italian island of Sardinia, where they were once abundant.
explanation: Sardines are tiny, oily fish your ancestors ate by the bucketload. They're bursting with vitamin D, calcium, and omega-3s that actually nourish your body. One of the most nutritious foods on the planet, hands down.

name: sardines in olive oil
fun_fact: Vintage sardine tins are aged like wine — some sell for over $50 a tin.
explanation: Sardines are tiny, oily fish that have been a staple in Mediterranean diets for centuries. They're rich in omega-3s, calcium, and vitamin D, making them a nutritional powerhouse. You're getting a concentrated dose of whole food goodness in every can.

name: sea bass
fun_fact: Called branzino in Italy, loup de mer in France, and suzuki in Japan.
explanation: Sea bass is full of protein and omega-3s your body craves. Wild-caught sea bass is a traditional catch that's been on menus for centuries – one of the purest forms of seafood you can eat.

name: sea bream
fun_fact: The most auspicious fish in Japan — served whole at celebrations.
explanation: Sea bream is a nutrient-dense fish rich in vitamin D and selenium, essential for immune function and cancer prevention. You've been eating it for centuries, just like your ancestors in the Mediterranean. One of the healthiest fish you can put on your plate.

name: shad
fun_fact: George Washington's army survived on shad during the brutal winter at Valley Forge.
explanation: Shad is a nutrient-dense fish high in vitamin D and omega-3s your body craves. Its traditional use in various cultures spans centuries, showcasing its long-standing value as a whole food. You're getting a wild, free-swimming fish that's a far cry from the factory-farmed nonsense.

name: sheepshead
fun_fact: Has eerily human-like teeth for crushing oyster shells and barnacles.
explanation: Sheepshead is a nutrient-dense fish rich in vitamin D and selenium, which your body needs to stay healthy. You'll find it in traditional coastal cuisine, where it's been a staple for centuries. One of the best fish options for a nutrient-packed meal.

name: skate
fun_fact: Skate wings develop a better flavor a day or two after being caught.
explanation: Skate is a nutrient-dense, low-mercury fish option rich in vitamin D and selenium. You've been eating its relatives, such as sturgeon and sharks, for centuries. A traditional seafood choice, skate is a reminder of the ocean's bounty that's worth preserving.

name: smelt
fun_fact: So small they're eaten whole — bones, head, and all.
explanation: Smelt is a nutrient-dense fish rich in vitamin D and selenium, two nutrients your body relies on for immune function and detoxification. Smelt have been a traditional food source for coastal communities for centuries, providing a burst of omega-3s and protein. One of the best small fish you can eat, if you can find it.

name: smoked salmon
fun_fact: Gravlax means 'buried salmon' — Vikings literally buried it in sand to cure it.
explanation: Smoked salmon is a nutrient-dense, traditional food that's been preserved for centuries. The smoking process enhances its flavor without compromising its rich omega-3 profile. You're getting a concentrated dose of healthy fats and protein in every bite.

name: snapper
fun_fact: Red snapper is so commonly mislabeled that studies found 73% of fish sold as snapper was something else.
explanation: Snapper is a nutrient-dense fish rich in protein, vitamin D, and selenium. You've been eating its ancestors for thousands of years, and it's a staple in many traditional cuisines. A well-cooked snapper fillet is one of the best things you can put on your plate.

name: sole
fun_fact: Dover sole was named after the English port of Dover where it was commonly landed.
explanation: Sole is one of the purest fish you can eat, with a delicate flavor and texture that's been prized for centuries. Rich in selenium and vitamin D, it's a nutrient-dense choice that's been a staple in traditional diets. A great choice for those looking for a clean and sustainable seafood option.

name: sprat
fun_fact: Smoked sprats are a beloved street food in Latvia, served on dark rye bread.
explanation: Sprat is a nutrient-dense fish bursting with omega-3s and vitamins. You've been eating its relatives for centuries - pilchards and sardines are essentially the same thing. One of the smallest, yet most valuable fish you can eat.

name: striped bass
fun_fact: The iconic fish of the Chesapeake Bay — Captain John Smith wrote about catching them in 1608.
explanation: Striped bass is a nutrient-dense fish rich in protein, omega-3s, and vitamin D. You've been eating this fish for centuries, and it's a staple in many coastal cultures where it's abundant. It's a wild-caught treasure that deserves a spot in your diet.

name: sturgeon
fun_fact: Sturgeons have been around for over 200 million years — they're older than dinosaurs.
explanation: You're getting a massive dose of vitamin D and selenium with every bite of sturgeon. This ancient fish has been a staple in traditional diets for thousands of years – its rich flavor and texture are a testament to its nutritional value. One of the most nutritious fish you can eat.

name: swordfish
fun_fact: A swordfish's bill can reach temperatures of up to 80°F warmer than surrounding water.
explanation: Swordfish is a rich source of vitamin D and selenium that your body craves. A traditional catch for seafaring cultures, it's a nutrient-dense food that's been fueling humans for centuries. One of the best fish you can eat, if you can catch it wild.

name: tilapia
fun_fact: Tilapia is one of the oldest farmed fish — ancient Egyptians raised them over 4,000 years ago.
explanation: Tilapia may be a cheap catch, but it's a far cry from the real deal. You're better off with wild-caught fish like salmon or sardines, but if you're stuck with tilapia, at least it's a fish, not a factory-farmed abomination. Still, it's a pale imitation of the seafood your ancestors ate.

name: tilefish
fun_fact: Lives in burrows it digs in the ocean floor, like an underwater prairie dog.
explanation: Tilefish is a nutrient-dense fish rich in selenium and vitamin D, essential for immune function and bone health. You've been eating variations of this fish for centuries, like the Mediterranean's sea bass. One of the most overlooked jewels in the ocean, it's a must-add to your seafood rotation.

name: trout
fun_fact: Rainbow trout and steelhead are actually the same species — the difference is lifestyle.
explanation: Trout is a lean, protein-rich fish that's been a staple in traditional diets for centuries. Its fatty acid profile is similar to that of salmon, with a high concentration of omega-3s that support heart health and brain function. You're getting a nutrient-dense meal when you eat wild-caught trout.

name: tuna
fun_fact: A single bluefin tuna sold for $3.1 million at a Tokyo auction in 2019.
explanation: Tuna is a nutrient-dense fish that's been a staple in many diets for centuries. Rich in protein, vitamins, and minerals, it's a food your body was designed to eat. Wild-caught tuna is one of the best sources of selenium and omega-3s on the planet.

name: turbot
fun_fact: Turbot was so prized by the Romans that they had special diamond-shaped platters made for it.
explanation: Turbot is a nutrient-dense fish rich in selenium and vitamin D, essential for immune function and bone health. This flatfish has been a staple in traditional cuisines for centuries, providing a sustainable seafood option for you to enjoy. One of the best fish you can eat, period.

name: vermillion snapper
fun_fact: A deep red snapper found in the Gulf of Mexico — lighter in flavor than red snapper.
explanation: You're getting a dose of vitamin D and selenium-rich protein with every bite of vermillion snapper. This Gulf of Mexico native is a traditional catch for coastal communities, providing a nutrient-dense meal that's been on the menu for centuries.

name: wahoo
fun_fact: Wahoo can swim at speeds up to 60 mph, making it one of the fastest fish in the ocean.
explanation: Wahoo is a nutrient-dense fish that's been a staple for coastal communities for centuries. Its rich omega-3 profile and high protein content make it a great choice for those looking to upgrade their diet. You're getting a real catch here, not some factory-farmed abomination.

name: walleye
fun_fact: Minnesota's state fish — the Friday night fish fry across the Midwest.
explanation: Walleye is a nutrient-dense fish that's been a staple in traditional diets for centuries. Rich in protein, omega-3s, and vitamins, it's a great source of energy for your body. You're getting a real meal when you eat wild-caught walleye.

name: white bass
fun_fact: A freshwater fish that runs up rivers in spring — the original fish fry fish.
explanation: White bass is a lean fish rich in protein and low in mercury, making it a great option for you. It's a traditional catch in many freshwater lakes and rivers, providing a sustainable source of nutrition. One of the best fish you can eat for a healthy diet.

name: whitefish
fun_fact: Whitefish is one of the most popular smoked fish in Jewish delicatessen cuisine.
explanation: Whitefish is a lean protein rich in vitamin D and selenium, which your body uses to shield itself from oxidative damage. You've been eating it for centuries, just like your ancestors did by the lake or the river. One of the most nutritious fish you can put on your plate.

name: wolffish
fun_fact: Has natural antifreeze in its blood to survive near-freezing Arctic waters.
explanation: Wolffish is a nutrient-dense catch from the deep, with a rich store of vitamin D and selenium. It's a traditional food source for coastal cultures, where it's been prized for its meaty flavor and oily texture. Eating wolfish is a chance to tap into the wild ocean's bounty.

name: wrasse
fun_fact: Can change sex from female to male — the largest female becomes the dominant male.
explanation: Wrasse is a nutrient-dense fish rich in selenium and vitamin D, essential for immune function and bone health. Its traditional role in Mediterranean cuisine is a testament to its value as a whole food. You can't replicate its complex flavor profile with factory-made alternatives.

name: yellowfin tuna
fun_fact: Called 'ahi' in Hawaiian — the fish behind seared ahi tuna steaks.
explanation: Yellowfin tuna is a fatty fish rich in protein and heart-healthy omega-3s that your body craves. You've been eating this in sushi for centuries, and it's a staple in many traditional diets. One of the best sources of real nutrition you can put on your plate.

name: yellowtail
fun_fact: Yellowtail hamachi is the most popular sushi fish in Japan.
explanation: Yellowtail is a nutrient-dense fish rich in selenium and vitamin D, essential for immune function and bone health. You've been eating this fish for centuries, just like your ancestors did in Japan and the Mediterranean. One of the best fish to add to your diet.

name: zander
fun_fact: Europe's most prized freshwater fish — the continental answer to walleye.
explanation: As a mild-flavored fish, zander is a nutrient-dense catch from European waters. Rich in protein and low in saturated fats, it's a traditional choice for those who value a healthy, satisfying meal. You're getting a real dose of omega-3s and essential fatty acids with every bite.

name: acai
fun_fact: Acai berries lose most of their antioxidant power within 24 hours of being picked.
explanation: Acai berries are a nutrient-dense fruit that's been a staple in the Amazon for centuries. Rich in antioxidants and fiber, they're a natural energy boost for your body. You're not getting the real deal if it's not frozen or dried from the fruit itself, though.

name: acai bowl
fun_fact: Frozen acai blended thick, topped with fruit and granola — a Brazilian beach staple.
explanation: Acai bowls are a processed abomination masquerading as a fruit dish. You're not getting the real deal - the frozen berries are often blended with sugar and other additives. In their natural state, acai berries are a nutritious, antioxidant-rich fruit, but when you're eating a bowl of processed goop, you're not getting the real thing.

name: ackee
fun_fact: Ackee is the national fruit of Jamaica but is toxic if eaten before it's fully ripe.
explanation: Ackee is a nutrient-dense fruit that's been a staple in Caribbean cuisine for centuries. Rich in protein, fiber, and vitamins, it's a food your body was designed to eat. Savor it in its natural state, not as a sugary jam or processed spread.

name: african star apple
fun_fact: Break it open and the star pattern inside reveals how it got its name.
explanation: African star apple is a nutrient-dense fruit you can forage in the wild, rich in vitamins and minerals like vitamin C and potassium. Its pulp is a traditional remedy in many cultures, and its unique flavor is a testament to nature's diversity. Eat it raw for a burst of flavor and nutrition.

name: ambarella
fun_fact: Also known as golden apple, it's crunchy when green and sweet when ripe.
explanation: Ambarella is a nutrient-dense fruit rich in vitamin C and antioxidants your body craves. Native to tropical regions, it's been a staple in traditional diets for centuries. Its tart flavor and crunchy texture make it a refreshing and satisfying snack.

name: apple
fun_fact: Apples float in water because they're 25% air.
explanation: Apples are a crunchy, sweet treat that's been fueling humans for thousands of years. Packed with fiber, antioxidants, and a hint of natural sweetness, they're a snack that's hard to beat. You can't get more real than biting into a fresh, juicy apple right off the tree.

name: apricot
fun_fact: Apricots were first cultivated in China over 4,000 years ago.
explanation: You're getting a burst of vitamin A and potassium from this sweet, juicy apricot, a fruit that's been eaten for thousands of years. Rich in fiber and antioxidants, it's a perfect snack for a quick energy boost. Nature's candy, if you will.

name: atemoya
fun_fact: A hybrid of sugar apple and cherimoya, often called 'pineapple sugar apple'.
explanation: Atemoya is a nutrient-dense fruit that's a natural hybrid of two tropical favorites - annona and papaya. Its rich blend of vitamins, minerals, and antioxidants is a gift from nature, providing sustained energy and satisfaction. You're getting a taste of the tropics with every juicy bite.

name: avocado
fun_fact: Avocados are technically berries, and they don't ripen on the tree.
explanation: Avocados are a nutrient-dense fruit that provides healthy fats, fiber, and various essential vitamins and minerals. You're meant to eat the whole fruit, not just the oil extracted from it. A ripe avocado is a perfect example of a whole food that supports your body's natural function.

name: babaco
fun_fact: A seedless relative of papaya that grows in the Ecuadorian highlands.
explanation: Babaco is a nutrient-dense fruit that's rich in vitamins A and C, potassium, and fiber. It's a member of the papaya family and traditionally consumed in its whole, unprocessed form. You're getting a healthy dose of antioxidants and beneficial compounds when you eat babaco as nature intended.

name: banana
fun_fact: Bananas are berries, but strawberries aren't.
explanation: Bananas are a nutrient-dense fruit that grew on trees humans used to climb. They're a rich source of potassium, a mineral your body needs to function. Eat them for a natural energy boost.

name: barberry
fun_fact: Used in Persian rice dishes, these tiny tart berries are packed with berberine.
explanation: Barberry is a nutrient-dense fruit high in vitamin C and antioxidants. You've been eating barberry for centuries, with traditional use dating back to ancient Greek and Roman medicine. Its tart flavor and numerous health benefits make it a food worth preserving.

name: bergamot
fun_fact: The essential oil from bergamot rind gives Earl Grey tea its distinctive flavor.
explanation: Bergamot is a nutrient-dense citrus fruit bursting with vitamin C and flavonoids. You've been eating bergamot's cousin, oranges, for centuries – it's a natural extension of that tradition. This underappreciated fruit deserves to be squeezed for its juice, not just its essential oil.

name: bilberry
fun_fact: RAF pilots in WWII reportedly ate bilberry jam to improve night vision.
explanation: Bilberries are a rich source of antioxidants and anthocyanins that your body craves. They're a traditional remedy for everything from digestive issues to eye health, and their dark, juicy flesh is a testament to their nutritional density. One of the celebrates fruits of the wild.

name: black mulberry
fun_fact: The stains are nearly impossible to wash out — a childhood badge of honor.
explanation: Black mulberries are a nutrient-dense fruit rich in antioxidants and fiber. Eaten for centuries in traditional medicine, they're a natural remedy for inflammation and digestive issues. One of the most ancient and nutritious fruits you can still find today.

name: black sapote
fun_fact: When ripe, the flesh looks and tastes remarkably like chocolate pudding.
explanation: You can't go wrong with black sapote - its creamy, sweet flesh is a nutrient-dense superfood rich in vitamins A and C, potassium, and fiber. This tropical fruit has been consumed for centuries in its native Mexico and Central America. Eat it raw or bake it into a delicious dessert.

name: blackberry
fun_fact: Blackberries are technically not berries — they're aggregate fruits.
explanation: Blackberries are bursting with antioxidants and fiber your body craves. They're a traditional foraging food that's been eaten for centuries. One of the best ways to get your daily dose of real nutrition.

name: blood orange
fun_fact: The deep red color comes from anthocyanins, rare in citrus fruits.
explanation: Blood oranges are a vibrant, nutrient-dense fruit bursting with vitamin C and antioxidants. You've been eating them for centuries, just like your ancestors, to boost immunity and fight off scurvy. Their unique flavor and deep color are a testament to their natural, unadulterated goodness.

name: blueberry
fun_fact: Blueberries are one of the only naturally blue foods.
explanation: Blueberries are bursting with antioxidants, fiber, and vitamins your body craves. They're a traditional summer treat that's been nourishing humans for centuries. One of the most nutrient-dense fruits you can eat.

name: boysenberry
fun_fact: Boysenberries are a cross between raspberries, blackberries, and loganberries.
explanation: You're getting a burst of antioxidants and fiber from the boysenberry's complex mix of vitamins and minerals. This ancient hybrid of raspberries, blackberries, and loganberries is a nutrient-dense treat that's been enjoyed for centuries. One of the best berries you can eat.

name: breadfruit
fun_fact: When cooked, breadfruit has a texture and taste similar to freshly baked bread.
explanation: Breadfruit is a nutrient-dense fruit that's been a staple in tropical cultures for centuries. Rich in fiber, vitamins, and minerals, it's a whole food that's easy to digest and provides sustained energy. You'll get a boost of potassium and other essential nutrients from this delicious, versatile fruit.

name: buddha's hand
fun_fact: This fragrant citrus has no juice or pulp — it's all zest and pith.
explanation: Buddha's hand is a citron variety with no edible pulp, but its aromatic oil-rich skin is what makes it a prized ingredient. You'll find it in traditional Chinese medicine and cooking, where its zest is used to add depth to teas and desserts. A true fruit, not some processed imitation.

name: cacao
fun_fact: It takes about 400 cacao beans to make one pound of chocolate.
explanation: Cacao is a nutrient-dense fruit that's been a staple in traditional diets for thousands of years. Rich in magnesium, flavonoids, and antioxidants, it's a treat that's as good for your body as it is for your taste buds. Savoring it in its raw, unprocessed form is the way to go.

name: calamansi
fun_fact: A staple in Filipino cooking, it's a cross between a kumquat and a mandarin.
explanation: Calamansi is a nutrient-dense citrus fruit that's been a staple in Southeast Asian cuisine for centuries. Rich in vitamin C and flavonoids, it's a natural immune booster and antioxidant powerhouse. Enjoy it fresh or use its juice to add flavor to your meals.

name: camu camu
fun_fact: Contains 60x more vitamin C per serving than an orange.
explanation: Camu camu is a nutrient-dense fruit that's been eaten by indigenous communities in the Amazon for centuries. Its high vitamin C content is off the charts, offering a natural immune boost you can't get from supplements. One of the most vitamin C-rich foods on the planet, camu camu is a superfood that deserves your attention.

name: canistel
fun_fact: Its dry, crumbly flesh tastes like sweet potato custard.
explanation: Canistel is a nutrient-dense fruit rich in vitamins A and C, potassium, and fiber. It's a traditional staple in Mexican cuisine, often eaten raw or used in jams and preserves. This sweet, starchy fruit is a natural fit for your diet.

name: cantaloupe
fun_fact: Cantaloupe is named after the Italian town of Cantalupo.
explanation: Cantaloupe is a nutrient-dense fruit bursting with vitamin C and beta-carotene. You've been eating it for centuries, just like your ancestors – it's a traditional summer treat that deserves a spot in your diet. One of the sweetest ways to get your daily dose of antioxidants.

name: cempedak
fun_fact: A close relative of jackfruit, popular deep-fried in Malaysia.
explanation: Cempedak is a nutrient-dense tropical fruit rich in vitamins and minerals, its unique flavor and texture a staple in Southeast Asian cuisine. You'll find it growing wild in its native regions, a testament to its natural, unaltered state. Eat it fresh or dried, either way, it's a nutrient powerhouse.

name: cherimoya
fun_fact: Mark Twain called cherimoya 'the most delicious fruit known to men.'
explanation: Cherimoya is a nutrient-dense fruit rich in vitamins A and C, potassium, and fiber. You'll find it in traditional markets and among Latin American cuisines, where it's been a staple for centuries. This tropical treat is a whole food your body will thank you for.

name: cherry
fun_fact: It takes about 250 cherries to make a cherry pie.
explanation: Cherries are a nutrient-dense fruit bursting with antioxidants and fiber - the perfect snack to satisfy your sweet tooth without sacrificing your health. They're a traditional treat that's been falls' favorite for centuries, and for good reason: they're a delicious way to get the nutrients your body craves.

name: clementine
fun_fact: Named after Father Clement Rodier, who discovered them in Algeria in 1902.
explanation: Clementines are a sweet and tangy burst of sunshine, bursting with vitamin C and flavonoids your body craves. You've been eating these tiny oranges for centuries, and they're a staple in traditional Mediterranean diets. One of the simplest, most nutritious snacks you can grab.

name: cloudberry
fun_fact: These golden Arctic berries can cost over $100 per pound.
explanation: You're getting a sweet dose of antioxidants and vitamins when you eat cloudberries, a rare and nutrient-dense fruit that grows in the wild. High in fiber and low in sugar, this tart treat is a traditional snack in Scandinavian cultures. It's a real food that's worth seeking out.

name: coconut
fun_fact: Coconut water can be used as a substitute for blood plasma in emergencies.
explanation: Coconut is a nutrient-dense fruit rich in healthy fats and fiber. You've been eating it for centuries, whether in tropical islands or as a staple in traditional diets. Its versatility and nutritional profile make it a vital food source for humans.

name: coconut cream
fun_fact: The thick layer that rises to the top of coconut milk — pure coconut fat.
explanation: Coconut cream is the rich, nutritious flesh of a mature coconut, a fruit your ancestors ate for centuries. Packed with healthy fats and fiber, it's a staple in traditional diets around the world. A delicious and satisfying addition to your plate.

name: cornelian cherry
fun_fact: Not a cherry at all — these sour red fruits make a tart jam in Turkey and Iran.
explanation: You're getting a dose of antioxidants and vitamins from the fruit that's been used for centuries in traditional medicine. Cornelian cherry is a nutrient-dense superfruit that's been consumed in its whole form, not some processed extract. It's a sweet and tangy treat that's been on the menu for humans since ancient times.

name: crabapple
fun_fact: All domestic apples are descended from wild crabapples.
explanation: Crabapple is a nutrient-dense fruit with a high concentration of fiber, vitamins, and antioxidants. You've been eating its relatives - apples - for thousands of years, and the smaller, tart crabapple is no exception. It's a wild, untamed fruit that's been a staple in traditional diets for centuries.

name: cranberry
fun_fact: Cranberries bounce when they're ripe — farmers use this to test quality.
explanation: Cranberries are a tart, nutrient-dense fruit that's been used for centuries to support urinary tract health. Rich in antioxidants and fiber, they're a traditional remedy that still holds up today. You'd be hard-pressed to find a more wholesome snack.

name: currant
fun_fact: Blackcurrants were banned in the US for nearly 100 years to protect pine trees.
explanation: Currants are a nutrient-dense, antioxidant-rich fruit that's been enjoyed for centuries. You'll find them in traditional baked goods and desserts, where their sweetness and flavor shine. These tiny fruits are a delicious way to get your daily dose of vitamins and minerals.

name: custard apple
fun_fact: Mark Twain called the cherimoya 'the most delicious fruit known to men'.
explanation: Custard apples are a nutrient-dense fruit rich in vitamins A and C, potassium, and fiber. You've been eating them for thousands of years, just like your ancestors in tropical regions. Enjoy the creamy pulp and seeds as nature intended.

name: damson
fun_fact: Damsons have been grown in Britain since Roman times.
explanation: Damsons are a nutrient-dense fruit rich in antioxidants and fiber, just like your ancestors ate before the dawn of modern agriculture. You'll find them in traditional British jams and preserves, where their tart flavor shines. Eating damsons is a taste of history.

name: damson plum
fun_fact: Too tart to eat raw but makes the finest plum jam and gin in England.
explanation: Damson plums are a nutrient-dense fruit rich in antioxidants and fiber, just like your grandmother used to make jam with. They're a type of stone fruit that's been enjoyed for centuries, and their tart flavor is a perfect addition to traditional recipes. Eating damson plums is a taste of history.

name: date
fun_fact: Date palms can produce fruit for over 100 years.
explanation: Dates are naturally sweet and bursting with potassium, fiber, and antioxidants. You've been eating them for thousands of years, just like our ancestors did in the Middle East. A handful of dates is a perfect snack to replenish your energy stores.

name: desert lime
fun_fact: Survives temperatures up to 120F in the Australian outback.
explanation: You're getting a burst of vitamin C and flavonoids from this tiny, tangy citrus fruit native to Australia. Desert limes have been a staple for Indigenous Australians for centuries, used in traditional medicine and cooking. One of the most nutrient-dense fruits you can eat.

name: dewberry
fun_fact: A trailing blackberry that grows low to the ground — sweeter than its upright cousin.
explanation: Dewberries are a type of wild, antioxidant-rich fruit that grows on thorny bushes - just like nature intended. You'd be hard-pressed to find a more traditional, nutrient-dense snack. Eat them fresh, preserved in honey, or freeze them for a burst of flavor and vitamins.

name: dragon fruit
fun_fact: Dragon fruit comes from a cactus that only blooms at night.
explanation: You're getting a dose of vitamin C and antioxidants from the vibrant pink flesh of dragon fruit, a tropical fruit that's been a staple in Southeast Asian diets for centuries. Its seeds and pulp provide a boost of fiber and healthy fats. A natural, nutrient-dense snack that's as close to nature as it gets.

name: dried fruit
fun_fact: Concentrated fruit sugar and nutrients — eat them sparingly, they're calorie-dense.
explanation: Dried fruit is a natural way to preserve the concentrated goodness of fresh fruit, rich in fiber, antioxidants, and natural sugars. You're getting a burst of nutrients in a convenient, shelf-stable package. Enjoy dates, apricots, and prunes as a healthy snack or add them to oatmeal or yogurt.

name: durian
fun_fact: Durian is banned on public transport in several Asian countries due to its smell.
explanation: Durian is a nutrient-dense fruit rich in healthy fats, vitamins, and minerals. Native to Southeast Asia, it's been a staple food for centuries. You're getting a concentrated dose of tropical nutrition when you eat durian.

name: egg fruit
fun_fact: Named for its texture — the flesh is dry and crumbly like a hard-boiled egg yolk.
explanation: Egg fruit is a nutrient-dense, tropical delight that's bursting with vitamins A and C, potassium, and fiber. Its unique texture and flavor have been enjoyed by humans for centuries, making it a traditional and wholesome choice. You'll be getting a natural energy boost with every bite.

name: elderberry
fun_fact: Raw elderberries are actually toxic — they must be cooked before eating.
explanation: Elderberry is a nutrient-dense fruit rich in antioxidants and vitamins, traditionally used to boost immunity and fight off infections. You've been eating this stuff for centuries, it's not some new-fangled supplement. Nature's medicine cabinet is stocked with elderberry.

name: elephant apple
fun_fact: So sour it makes your eyes water — elephants love them, hence the name.
explanation: You're getting a dose of antioxidants and polyphenols when you eat elephant apple, a fruit rich in compounds that help protect your cells from damage. It's a traditional food in many cultures, often eaten raw or used in jams and preserves. This ancient fruit is one of the few that's still relatively untouched by modern agriculture.

name: feijoa
fun_fact: Feijoa petals are edible and taste like cotton candy.
explanation: Feijoa is a nutrient-dense fruit rich in vitamins A and C, potassium, and fiber. Its traditional use in South American cuisine dates back centuries, and its unique flavor profile is a staple in many ancestral diets. You're getting a taste of the real deal.

name: fig
fun_fact: Figs are technically inverted flowers, not fruits.
explanation: Figs are a nutrient-dense fruit rich in fiber, potassium, and antioxidants. You've been eating them for thousands of years, just like your ancestors did in the Mediterranean. A sweet, whole food that's as close to nature as it gets.

name: finger lime
fun_fact: The tiny juice vesicles pop like caviar, earning it the nickname 'citrus caviar'.
explanation: Finger lime is a nutrient-dense fruit that's been used by indigenous Australians for centuries. Its unique caviar-like pulp bursts with flavor and is rich in vitamins and minerals. Eating finger lime is a taste of traditional culture that's worth preserving.

name: fruit salad
fun_fact: Nature's dessert — no sugar needed when the fruit is ripe.
explanation: Fruit salad is a collection of whole, nutrient-dense fruits like berries, citrus, and stone fruits - all foods your body was designed to eat. Each piece of fruit brings its own unique blend of vitamins, minerals, and antioxidants. A colorful mix of seasonal fruits is a simple, satisfying way to nourish your body.

name: gac fruit
fun_fact: Contains 70x more lycopene than tomatoes — the Vietnamese call it 'fruit from heaven'.
explanation: Gac fruit is a nutrient-dense superfood that's been consumed for centuries in traditional Vietnamese and Chinese cuisine. Rich in beta-carotene and other essential vitamins and minerals, it's one of the most nutritious fruits you can eat. Its unique flavor and vibrant orange color make it a standout among other fruits.

name: genip
fun_fact: Kids in the Caribbean eat these like candy, cracking the shell with their teeth.
explanation: Genip is a nutrient-dense fruit that's been used for centuries in traditional medicine and cooking. Its rich antioxidant profile and high water content make it a refreshing and rejuvenating snack. Eating genip is a great way to support your body's natural detoxification processes.

name: giant granadilla
fun_fact: The largest passion fruit species — can grow to a foot long.
explanation: Giant granadilla is a nutrient-dense fruit rich in vitamins A and C, potassium, and fiber. Its pulp and seeds have been consumed by indigenous cultures for centuries, providing a natural source of energy and essential nutrients. You're getting a taste of the Amazon when you eat this tropical treasure.

name: goji berry
fun_fact: Goji berries have been used in traditional Chinese medicine for over 2,000 years.
explanation: Goji berries are a nutrient-dense superfood that's been consumed for centuries in traditional Tibetan and Chinese medicine. Rich in antioxidants and vitamins, they're a natural way to boost your immune system and support eye health. You can't get this kind of nutrition from a lab-made supplement – only from the real thing.

name: golden berry
fun_fact: The Incas cultivated these in the Sacred Valley of Peru over 4,000 years ago.
explanation: Golden berries are a nutrient-dense superfruit rich in antioxidants and vitamins. You can find them in the Andean region, where they've been a staple food for centuries. Enjoy them as a sweet and tangy snack, straight from the bush.

name: gooseberry
fun_fact: Gooseberries were once banned in the US because they spread a disease that killed pine trees.
explanation: Gooseberries are a nutrient-dense fruit bursting with vitamin C and antioxidants. You've been eating them for centuries, just like your ancestors – no need for fancy processing or added sugars. A true superfood that's as wild as you are.

name: granadilla
fun_fact: Unlike its sour cousin passion fruit, granadilla is naturally sweet.
explanation: Granadilla is a nutrient-dense fruit bursting with vitamin C and antioxidants your body craves. Its seeds, rind, and pulp are all edible, just like nature intended. A true superfood that's been a staple in traditional diets for centuries.

name: grape
fun_fact: It takes about 2.5 pounds of grapes to make one bottle of wine.
explanation: Grapes are a nutrient-dense fruit bursting with antioxidants and fiber. You've been eating them for thousands of years, and it's no wonder - they're a natural source of sweetness and a healthy snack. Nature's candy is the best kind.

name: grapefruit
fun_fact: Grapefruit can interact with over 85 medications.
explanation: Grapefruit is a nutrient-dense fruit that's bursting with vitamin C and antioxidants. Its high water content and fiber make it a refreshing and filling snack. You're meant to eat the whole thing, not just the juice.

name: grumichama
fun_fact: A rare Brazilian cherry tree that produces intensely sweet dark purple fruit.
explanation: You're getting a taste of the Amazon with this tart, tropical fruit - packed with vitamins and antioxidants that'll keep your immune system firing on all cylinders. Grumichama's been a staple in traditional medicine for centuries, and its unique flavor profile is a nod to the wild foods our ancestors devoured.

name: guacamole
fun_fact: The Aztec word 'ahuacamolli' means 'avocado sauce' — they invented it.
explanation: Guacamole is made from avocados, a nutrient-dense fruit your ancestors crushed for centuries. Avocados provide healthy fats, fiber, and antioxidants, making them a staple in traditional diets. You're eating a fruit that's been a cornerstone of human nutrition for thousands of years.

name: guanabana
fun_fact: The same fruit as soursop — called guanabana in Latin America.
explanation: Guanabana is a nutrient-dense fruit rich in vitamin C and potassium, often eaten fresh or used in traditional desserts. You've been eating this tropical gem for centuries, it's a staple in many cultures. Its unique flavor and texture are a result of its natural growth in the wild.

name: guava
fun_fact: Guava has four times the vitamin C of an orange.
explanation: Guavas are a nutrient-dense fruit rich in vitamin C, potassium, and antioxidants your body craves. Traditionally eaten whole or made into jams, guavas are a staple in many tropical cultures where they've been consumed for centuries. One of the most nutritious fruits you can eat.

name: honeyberry
fun_fact: An Arctic berry that can survive -47C — now a darling of cold-climate fruit growers.
explanation: Honeyberries are the wild cousins of blueberries, bursting with antioxidants and fiber. You're getting a taste of the wild, just like our ancestors did. A sweet treat that's actually good for you.

name: honeydew
fun_fact: Honeydew melons are in the same family as cucumbers and squash.
explanation: Honeydew is a refreshing, nutrient-dense fruit that's essentially a watermelon on steroids. Its high water content and rich stores of vitamin C will quench your thirst and boost your immune system. Eat it as is, or slice it up for a sweet and tangy snack.

name: horned melon
fun_fact: Horned melon tastes like a combination of banana, cucumber, and lime.
explanation: Horned melon is a nutrient-dense fruit rich in vitamin C and antioxidants. Its unique, spiky exterior is a natural defense mechanism, and its pulp is a refreshing, hydrating treat. Eating it seasonal and in its whole form keeps you connected to nature's bounty.

name: huckleberry
fun_fact: They cannot be commercially cultivated — every huckleberry is wild-picked.
explanation: Huckleberries are a nutrient-dense superfood that grows wild in the Americas. You can forage them in the summer months when ripe, or buy them frozen to بت your own pies and jams. A true wild fruit that's been a staple for indigenous communities for centuries.

name: ice cream bean
fun_fact: The cottony pulp inside the giant pods tastes like vanilla ice cream.
explanation: You're reaching for a sweet treat that's actually a fruit, not a processed dessert. Ice cream beans are rich in vitamins and minerals, and their creamy pulp is a natural source of sugar, just like nature intended. Enjoy this tropical delight as a refreshing, whole food snack.

name: indian gooseberry
fun_fact: The cornerstone of Ayurvedic medicine for 3,000+ years — incredibly sour but nutritious.
explanation: Indian gooseberry is a nutrient-dense fruit bursting with vitamin C and antioxidants your body craves. It's been used in traditional Ayurvedic medicine for centuries to boost immunity and overall health. You'll do well to incorporate this tangy, sour gem into your diet.

name: jabuticaba
fun_fact: Jabuticaba fruits grow directly on the trunk of the tree, not on branches.
explanation: You're getting a taste of the Amazon's best-kept secret: jabuticaba's antioxidant-rich, dark purple fruit is bursting with vitamins and minerals your body craves. This ancient fruit has been a staple for centuries, and its unique flavor is a testament to nature's perfection. Eat it fresh, and experience the raw power of the wild.

name: jackfruit
fun_fact: Jackfruit is the largest tree-borne fruit in the world, weighing up to 80 pounds.
explanation: Jackfruit is a nutrient-dense tropical fruit rich in vitamins and minerals, with a rich history of traditional use in Indian and Southeast Asian cuisine. You'll find it's a good source of fiber, antioxidants, and potassium, making it a valuable addition to a balanced diet. Whole jackfruit is a natural, unprocessed food that's been eaten for centuries.

name: jambul
fun_fact: It stains your tongue deep purple and has been used in Ayurvedic medicine for millennia.
explanation: Jambul is a nutrient-dense fruit rich in antioxidants and fiber, its traditional use dating back to ancient Ayurvedic medicine. You can find it in tropical regions, where it's been a staple for centuries. Its unique flavor and numerous health benefits make it a valuable addition to your diet.

name: java apple
fun_fact: Bell-shaped and watery-crisp — one of the most refreshing tropical fruits.
explanation: Java apples are a nutrient-dense fruit your body craves. Rich in fiber, antioxidants, and a hint of sweetness, they're a traditional snack your ancestors devoured. One of the best ways to get your daily dose of whole food goodness.

name: jujube
fun_fact: Dried jujubes have been found in Chinese tombs dating back 7,000 years.
explanation: You're getting a dose of vitamins A and C, potassium, and antioxidants from this ancient fruit that's been eaten for thousands of years. Jujube's natural sweetness and adaptogenic properties make it a traditional remedy in many cultures. Eat it fresh or dried – either way, it's a nutrient-dense treat.

name: kaffir lime
fun_fact: The bumpy, wrinkled skin is unmistakable — the leaves are more prized than the fruit.
explanation: You'll find kaffir lime's high vitamin C content and unique flavor profile in traditional Southeast Asian cuisine. Its zest and juice add depth to curries and marinades, while its seeds and leaves are used in teas and soups. A true gem of a fruit from the tropics.

name: key lime
fun_fact: Smaller and more aromatic than Persian limes, they're the real Key lime pie ingredient.
explanation: Key limes are the real deal, bursting with vitamin C and flavonoids that actually do something for you. You're not getting any of that from a bag of sugary "lime" powder. Eating a whole key lime is a taste of sunshine.

name: kiwano
fun_fact: The spiky orange shell hides lime-green jelly-like flesh tasting of cucumber and banana.
explanation: Kiwano is a nutrient-dense fruit bursting with vitamins A and C, potassium, and antioxidants. Its unique flavor and texture have been enjoyed for centuries in traditional African and Asian cuisine. As a whole, unprocessed food, kiwano is a delicious way to nourish your body.

name: kiwi
fun_fact: Kiwis have more vitamin C per ounce than oranges.
explanation: Kiwi is a nutrient-dense fruit bursting with vitamin C, potassium, and fiber. You've evolved to crave its sweet-tart taste, which signals a hit of antioxidants and a boost to your immune system. Eat it whole, skin and all, for the full nutritional punch.

name: korean melon
fun_fact: Yellow with white stripes — sweet, crunchy, and eaten like an apple in Korea.
explanation: You're getting a sweet and refreshing dose of water and electrolytes from Korean melon's high water content and natural sugars. Its seeds and rind are also edible, providing a good source of fiber and antioxidants. A traditional summer snack in Korea, it's a simple, unprocessed treat your body will thank you for.

name: kumquat
fun_fact: Kumquats are the only citrus fruit you eat whole — skin and all.
explanation: You're getting a burst of vitamin C and antioxidants from the kumquat's tiny, edible skin. This ancient fruit has been eaten whole for thousands of years, its sweet and sour taste a delight to the senses. It's a nutrient-dense snack that's as close to nature as it gets.

name: kwai muk
fun_fact: A tiny Chinese fig relative with a sweet, strawberry-like flesh.
explanation: Kwai muk is a nutrient-dense fruit, rich in vitamins and minerals your body craves. Native to Southeast Asia, it's been a staple food for centuries, providing sustenance for local communities. Its unique combination of flavors and textures is a natural delight.

name: langsat
fun_fact: Translucent flesh in grape-like clusters — a beloved street food across Southeast Asia.
explanation: Langsat is a nutrient-dense fruit rich in vitamins A and C, potassium, and fiber. Native to Southeast Asia, it's been a staple food for centuries. You'll find it's a far cry from the sugary, mass-produced fruits often found in supermarkets.

name: lemon
fun_fact: Lemons contain more sugar than strawberries.
explanation: Lemons are a nutrient-dense fruit that's been used for centuries to add flavor and medicine to your diet.diagagnosed with scurvy, sailors would drink lemon juice to prevent the disease. You can feel good about squeezing fresh lemon juice into your water or salad dressing.

name: lemon drop mangosteen
fun_fact: Tastes like lemonade in fruit form — a Bolivian treasure only recently known outside South America.
explanation: Lemon drop mangosteen is a nutrient-dense fruit rich in vitamins and antioxidants. You can find it in tropical markets, and its unique flavor profile is a refreshing twist on traditional mangosteen. This lesser-known variety is a legitimate whole food your body will thank you for.

name: lime
fun_fact: British sailors earned the nickname 'limeys' because they ate limes to prevent scurvy.
explanation: Limes are a nutrient-dense superfood your body craves. Rich in vitamin C and flavonoids, they've been used for centuries to boost immunity and flavor traditional dishes. One of the most healing fruits you can eat.

name: lingonberry
fun_fact: IKEA serves 600 million Swedish meatballs a year, nearly all with lingonberry jam.
explanation: Lingonberries are a nutrient-dense superfood your ancestors foraged for in the wild. Rich in antioxidants and fiber, they're a natural remedy for digestive issues and inflammation. Eating them raw or cooked is a great way to tap into the traditional Scandinavian diet.

name: longan
fun_fact: Longan means 'dragon eye' in Chinese because the fruit resembles an eyeball when peeled.
explanation: You're eating a nutrient-dense fruit that's been consumed for centuries in traditional Asian cultures. Longan is rich in vitamins, minerals, and antioxidants that support immune function and protect against oxidative stress. It's a whole food that's been part of human diets for thousands of years.

name: loquat
fun_fact: Loquats are one of the few fruit trees that bloom in autumn and ripen in early spring.
explanation: Loquat is a nutrient-dense fruit rich in vitamins A and C, potassium, and fiber. Eaten for centuries in traditional Chinese medicine, its sweet and slightly tart taste is a natural treat. You're getting a dose of real nutrition when you bite into a juicy loquat.

name: lucuma
fun_fact: Peru's most popular ice cream flavor — more popular than chocolate or vanilla.
explanation: Lucuma is a nutrient-dense fruit rich in vitamins A and C, potassium, and fiber. Native to the Andes, its sweet, maple-like flavor has been savored by many cultures for centuries. As a whole, unprocessed fruit, lucuma is one of the best ways to get your daily dose of essential vitamins and minerals.

name: lychee
fun_fact: Lychee has been cultivated in China for over 2,000 years.
explanation: Lychee is a nutrient-dense fruit rich in vitamin C and potassium, a traditional staple in Southeast Asian and Chinese cuisine. You've been eating this ancient fruit for thousands of years – it's a natural, whole food your body thrives on. Lychee's unique flavor and texture are a taste of nature.

name: madrono
fun_fact: The only fruit in the EU that ferments on the tree — birds eating them get tipsy.
explanation: Madrono is a nutrient-dense, antioxidant-rich fruit that's native to the Americas. You can forage for it in the wild, where it grows on tall trees, and it's a staple in traditional Mexican cuisine. Its tart flavor and versatility make it a delicious addition to your diet.

name: makrut lime fruit
fun_fact: Bumpy and nearly juiceless — the zest is prized but the leaves even more so.
explanation: Makrut lime's thick, bumpy skin and tart pulp are a package deal that's been fueling Southeast Asian cuisine for centuries. Rich in vitamin C and flavonoids, it's a nutrient-dense superfruit that's worth eating whole, not just its juice. You'll get the most benefits from the entire fruit, not just the extract.

name: mamey sapote
fun_fact: The creamy salmon-colored flesh is the base of Cuba's national milkshake.
explanation: Mamey sapote is a nutrient-dense fruit rich in vitamins A and C, potassium, and fiber. Its rich, custard-like pulpXem is a traditional treat in Central America and Mexico, where it's been consumed for centuries. You're getting a taste of real tropical nutrition with every bite.

name: mandarin
fun_fact: More than 30 million tonnes are produced yearly, mostly in China.
explanation: Mandarins are bursting with vitamin C and flavonoids that your immune system depends on. You've been eating them for thousands of years - they're a staple in traditional Chinese cuisine. One of the healthiest snacks you can grab.

name: mango
fun_fact: Mangoes are the most consumed fruit in the world.
explanation: Mangoes are a nutrient-dense fruit your body thrives on, rich in vitamins A and C, potassium, and fiber. They're a staple in traditional diets around the world, particularly in tropical regions where they grow in abundance. You can't go wrong with a ripe, juicy mango.

name: mangosteen
fun_fact: Mangosteen was once banned from import to the US because of fruit fly concerns.
explanation: Mangosteen is a nutrient-dense tropical fruit rich in vitamins and antioxidants your body craves. Its purple rind and soft white interior have been a staple in Southeast Asian cuisine for centuries. A true superfood that's been around for thousands of years.

name: marang
fun_fact: A jackfruit relative from the Philippines with cotton-candy-sweet flesh.
explanation: Marang is a nutrient-dense fruit rich in vitamins A and C, potassium, and fiber. You likely won't find it in your average grocery store, but its traditional use in Southeast Asia speaks to its value as a whole food humans have been eating for centuries. Its sweet flavor and versatility make it a true gem.

name: marionberry
fun_fact: Named after Marion County, Oregon — the official berry of the state.
explanation: You're getting a burst of antioxidants and fiber from the marionberry's thick skin and juicy pulp. This sweet-tart treasure is a descendant of the blackberry, a traditional favorite in the Pacific Northwest. Eat it fresh or bake it into a pie – either way, it's a treat for your taste buds and your body.

name: maypop
fun_fact: The only passion fruit species native to North America.
explanation: Maypop is a nutrient-dense fruit rich in vitamin C and antioxidants. It's a traditional food source for many populations, particularly in the southeastern United States. You'll find it growing wild in its native habitat, a testament to its hardiness and adaptability.

name: medlar
fun_fact: One of the few fruits that must rot (blet) before it becomes edible.
explanation: Medlars are a nutrient-dense fruit that's been consumed for centuries, often eaten raw or used in jams and preserves. Their unique flavor and texture are a result of their high tannin content, which also makes them a natural astringent. You'll find them listed in medieval cookbooks and still growing in traditional orchards today.

name: meyer lemon
fun_fact: A cross between a lemon and a mandarin, rediscovered by Alice Waters in the 1990s.
explanation: Meyer lemons are a nutrient-dense fruit, bursting with vitamin C and flavonoids that support immune function and overall health. You've been eating their ancestors for thousands of years, from ancient China to Mediterranean cuisine. This sweet-tart citrus is a true superfood.

name: miracle fruit
fun_fact: Miracle fruit makes sour foods taste sweet for up to an hour after eating it.
explanation: Miracle fruit is a nutrient-dense fruit that's been consumed for centuries in West Africa. Its unique properties allow it to temporarily alter your taste buds, but it's the fruit's rich vitamin C, potassium, and fiber content that truly make it shine. You're getting a valuable dose of real nutrition with every bite.

name: mock strawberry
fun_fact: Looks identical to a strawberry but tastes like absolutely nothing.
explanation: Mock strawberry is a cheap impostor, lacking the fiber, vitamins, and antioxidants found in real strawberries. You're better off eating actual strawberries, which are a nutrient-dense fruit humans have been enjoying for centuries. Don't settle for a fake.

name: mountain apple
fun_fact: A teardrop-shaped tropical fruit with crisp, rose-scented flesh.
explanation: You're getting a dose of real fiber and antioxidants with every bite of mountain apple. This wild fruit has been a staple for centuries, its tartness a refreshing contrast to the sweetness of modern fruits. Nature's candy, minus the added sugars.

name: mulberry
fun_fact: Silkworms eat only mulberry leaves.
explanation: Mulberries are a nutrient-dense fruit with a burst of antioxidants and vitamins. You've been eating them for thousands of years, just like your ancestors did in ancient China and Greece. Enjoy them fresh or dried – either way, you're getting a taste of real history.

name: muscadine
fun_fact: Native American grapes with thick skins — you eat them by squeezing the pulp out.
explanation: Muscadine grapes are a nutrient-dense treasure, bursting with antioxidants and polyphenols that your body craves. Native to the southeastern US, this ancient fruit has been consumed by humans for thousands of years. One of the healthiest things you can put in your body.

name: nance
fun_fact: These tiny yellow fruits smell like dirty cheese but taste sweet and oily.
explanation: Apricots are a nutrient-dense fruit your body craves. They're rich in vitamin A and potassium, essential for healthy vision and blood pressure. Nature's candy is better than the artificial stuff.

name: natal plum
fun_fact: The only part of this otherwise toxic plant that's safe to eat.
explanation: Natal plum is a nutrient-dense fruit rich in antioxidants and vitamins your body craves. Its traditional use dates back to indigenous South African communities, who prized it for its medicinal and culinary value. One of the most underrated fruits you can eat.

name: nectarine
fun_fact: Genetically almost identical to peaches — a single gene controls the fuzz.
explanation: Nectarines are a stone fruit that your body craves for their natural sweetness and fiber. They're a staple in traditional diets, where they're savored fresh or used in jams and preserves. One of the sweetest and most satisfying fruits you can eat.

name: noni
fun_fact: Noni fruit smells so bad it's sometimes called 'vomit fruit.'
explanation: Noni is a nutrient-dense fruit rich in vitamins A and C, potassium, and antioxidants your body craves. Polynesians have revered it for centuries, using it to boost energy and immunity. You'll find it growing wild in tropical climates, a true fruit of the earth.

name: oil palm fruit
fun_fact: The bright red-orange fruit that produces the world's most consumed vegetable oil.
explanation: You're getting a taste of the tropical wild with oil palm fruit, a nutrient-dense snack rich in vitamins and minerals. In its whole form, it's a traditional food source for many cultures, providing a burst of energy and flavor. Eat it fresh or dried to reap its benefits.

name: orange
fun_fact: The color orange was named after the fruit, not the other way around.
explanation: You get a burst of vitamin C and flavonoids from an orange, which is like a natural shield against oxidative stress. In the winter, when other fruits are scarce, oranges are a reliable source of sweetness and nutrition. A whole orange is a perfect snack, no added sugars or preservatives needed.

name: otaheite apple
fun_fact: Captain Bligh of the Bounty introduced this fruit to the Caribbean.
explanation: You're getting a taste of a tropical gem that's been around since ancient times. Otaheite apples are a nutrient-dense, low-sugar fruit packed with antioxidants and fiber, and have been a staple in Pacific Island diets for centuries. They're a true fruit, not some hybrid or genetically modified abomination.

name: pandanus fruit
fun_fact: Looks like an alien planet — each segment can be sucked for sweet juice.
explanation: Pandanus fruit is a nutrient-dense powerhouse rich in vitamins, minerals, and antioxidants your body craves. Native to tropical regions, it's been a staple food for centuries, providing sustenance for indigenous communities. Eating pandanus fruit is a trip back to traditional eating.

name: papaya
fun_fact: Papaya contains an enzyme called papain that can tenderize meat.
explanation: Papaya is a nutrient-dense tropical fruit rich in vitamins A and C, potassium, and an enzyme called papain that helps with digestion. You've been eating papaya for thousands of years, a staple in many ancient cultures. Eat it fresh or dried, but avoid the sugary canned versions.

name: passion fruit
fun_fact: Passion fruit is named after the Passion of Christ, not romantic passion.
explanation: Passion fruit is a nutrient-dense fruit bursting with vitamins A and C, potassium, and fiber. It's a tropical treat that's been a staple in many cultures for centuries, its unique flavor and texture a natural result of its whole, unprocessed form. You're getting a real dose of nature when you eat a fresh passion fruit.

name: pawpaw
fun_fact: The largest edible fruit native to North America, tasting like banana custard.
